questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduces blood pressure primarily by directly decreasing the heart rate?
questions.solution:
Propranolol reduces blood pressure by directly decreasing the heart rate. It is a nonselective beta-blocker and blocks the beta 1 receptor of the heart (SA node) thus reducing the heart rate and blood pressure.

It also reduces renin secretion by blocking beta 1 receptors in JG cells. Reduction in renin release also contributes to blood pressure reduction.

Option B: Prazosin is a selective alpha 1 blocker and dilates both arteries and veins and may cause reflex tachycardia.

Option C: Alpha methyldopa is a selective alpha 2 receptor agonist. Alpha 2 receptors are autoreceptors present on the presynaptic membrane. On stimulation, central sympathetic discharge is reduced. Alpha methyldopa can indirectly reduce heart rate.

Option D: Nitroprusside is a vasodilator and may cause reflex tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a prostacyclin analog that can be added to the treatment regimen of a patient with pulmonary artery hypertension?
questions.solution:
Iloprost is a prostacyclin analog indicated in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension. It falls under the category of IP receptor (prostacyclin receptor) agonists.

Other drugs falling under the category of IP receptor agonists are:

  • Epoprostenol

  • Treprostinil

  • Iloprost

  • Selexipag

Option A: Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor. 

Option B: Misoprostol is a synthetic PGE1 analog. 

Option C: Dinoprost is a natural PGF2-alpha preparation. It should not be confused with dinoprostone which is a synthetic analogue of PGE2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of both feet and of breathlessness on exertion. After evaluation, she was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with cardiac failure.

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 23-year-old hypothyroid patient taking levothyroxine regularly has now become pregnant. What would your advice be regarding levothyroxine?

choices.text: Switch to liothyronine as levothyroxine is teratogenic
Increase the dose as pregnancy causes an increased demand for levothyroxine
Continue the same dose but monitor the serum levels on a fortnightly basis
Stop levothyroxine till the end of the first trimester as it has teratogenic potential

questions.solution:
The dose of levothyroxine in patients who become pregnant should usually be increased. This is because demand for levothyroxine increases in pregnancy and low thyroxine levels are associated with adverse fetal outcomes such as mental retardation. 

The dose of levothyroxine is increased by 30-50% by asking the patient to take 2 extra pills per week. Increased demand for levothyroxine in pregnancy is due to:

  • The increased serum concentration of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) induced by estrogen
  • Increased expression of type 3 deiodinase in the placenta
  • A small amount of passage of levothyroxine to the fetus

Thyroid hormones are not teratogenic. Liothyronine is not preferred in pregnancy because T3 has a short half-life and requires frequent dosing to limit large fluctuations in levels. In addition, excess T3 often acts to normalize TSH while lowering T4, thereby risking inadequate T4 availability to the fetus.

questions.text: Z track technique is used for?

choices.text: Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

questions.solution:
The Z-track technique is used for the intramuscular administration of long-acting depot antipsychotics.

Advantages: 

  • The 'Z-track' prevents leakage of the medication into the subcutaneous tissue and skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin
  • Pain intensity is also reduced

questions.text: The maximum approved daily dose of Istradefylline is:
questions.solution:
The maximum approved daily dose of Istradefylline is 40 mg.

Istradefylline has been recently approved by FDA as an add-on treatment to levodopa in adults with Parkinson’s disease experiencing off episodes.

It is an adenosine A2A receptor antagonist.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is resistant to tetracyclines?
questions.solution:
All strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are resistant to the action of tetracyclines.

Tetracyclines are active against MRSA and MSSA. Doxycycline and minocycline can be used in cutaneous MRSA infections.

Rickettsia and chlamydia are highly susceptible to tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are considered first line agents for chlamydial infections like non-specific urethritis/ endocervicitis and rickettsial infections like typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever.

They are also second-line drugs in patients with syphilis who are allergic to penicillin.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic drugs which are more active against gram-positive than gram-negative. They are effective against spirochetes, Haemophilus ducreyi, Vibrio cholera, Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

questions.text: An infant had a serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. The mother might have taken which of the following drugs during the third trimester for this to occur?
questions.solution:
Cotrimoxazole is a combination drug consisting of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, of which sulfamethoxazole is a sulfonamide. Sulphonamides displace bilirubin from plasma albumin, leading to elevation of serum bilirubin levels.

These drugs can cross the placenta and are secreted in milk and can therefore cause kernicterus in newborn infants if they are given to pregnant women near term or during lactation.

questions.text: You notice fenoldopam mentioned on the drug chart of an elderly male patient admitted in the ICU. What condition is he most likely being treated for?
questions.solution:
Fenoldopam is primarily indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies. It is a D1 agonist at peripheral D1 receptors and acts as a rapid-acting vasodilator.

Drugs used in a hypertensive emergency are:

  • Nitroprusside
  • Nicardipine
  • Labetalol
  • Hydralazine
  • Esmolol
  • Nitroglycerine
  • Phentolamine
  • Fenoldopam

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding inverse agonists?

choices.text: Binds to the receptor and causes maximum action
Binds to the receptor and causes opposite action to that of agonist
Binds to the receptor and causes no action
Binds to the receptor and causes submaximal action

questions.solution:
Inverse agonists bind to the receptor and cause an action opposite to that of an agonist.

Type of drugs

Intrinsic activity

Agonists

1

Partial agonists

0 to 1

Competitive antagonists

0

Inverse agonists

0 to -1

The ability of the drug to bind with a receptor is called affinity.

The capacity of a drug to induce a functional change in the receptor is called intrinsic activity or efficacy.

questions.text: A patient showing treatment failure with multiple antiretroviral drugs is now started on maraviroc. This drug acts against:
questions.solution:
Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist acting against the CCR5 receptor.

It binds to the host cell CCR-5 receptor and prevents the binding of viral GP-120 to host cells. It is indicated in patients with evidence of infection with predominantly CCR-5 tropic virus.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia was started on a class1B anti-arrhythmic drug. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Mexiletine is a class 1B antiarrhythmic drug. It is a lidocaine analog.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with wet age-related macular degeneration is being administered ranibizumab intravitreally. All of the following are known side effects of the drug, except _______.
questions.solution:
Ranibizumab is associated with a raise in IOP, not a fall.

Ranibizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against VEGF-A (vascular endothelial growth factor-A). Ranibizumab is indicated in wet age-related macular degeneration and is used intravitreally where it inhibits VEGF-A induced ocular neovascularization.

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a patient who presented with fever and cough with expectoration is shown below. Following discussion, a lincosamide antibiotic is prescribed. Which of the following will you choose?
questions.solution:
Clindamycin, a lincosamide is used in the management of lung abscess and anaerobic lung and pleural space infections.

Clindamycin is a congener of lincomycin and binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes and inhibits protein synthesis.

Option A: Telithromycin is a ketolide antibiotic.

Option B: Spectinomycin is an aminocyclitol antibiotic that binds to the 30S subunit of ribosomes and inhibits protein synthesis.

Option D: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic.

questions.text: Polymyxins are effective against:
questions.solution:
Polymyxins are effective against gram-negative bacteria.

Polymyxin group of antibiotics includes polymyxin B and colistin which have their antimicrobial spectrum limited primarily to gram-negative aerobic bacteria. They interact with the phospholipid of the bacterial cell membranes and disrupt it.

Polymyxins are used in various topical formulations. Parenteral formulations are used only in serious systemic infections that are resistant to other antimicrobials. Nephrotoxicity limits widespread systemic use.

questions.text: A 40-year old man who is suffering from open-angle glaucoma reads about netarsudil being approved as a novel agent for his condition. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution: Netarsudil is a rho kinase inhibitor that acts by relaxing the trabecular meshwork. This increases the outflow of aqueous humor and reduces intraocular pressure.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for type IIa and IIb hyperlipoproteinemias?
questions.solution:
The drugs of choice for type IIa and IIb hyperlipoproteinemias are statins. 

In type IIa or IIb hyperlipoproteinemias, there is increased LDL cholesterol with +/- increase in TG.  Statins have the maximum LDL lowering property among the hypolipidemic drugs. Therefore, they are the drugs of choice in this case.

In type III/IV hyperlipoproteinemias, there is mainly an increase in triglyceride(TG) level. Fibrates reduce the TGs contained in VLDL and increase the HDL. So they are the drugs of choice for these conditions.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following rifamycins is not used for mycobacterial infections?
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is not used for mycobacterial infections. It is a synthetic rifamycin that is poorly absorbed from the GIT and is indicated in the management of GI conditions like: 

  • Traveler’s diarrhea
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea
  • Hepatic encephalopathy

Rifamycins indicated in mycobacterial infections are rifampicin, rifapentine, and rifabutin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis develops ascites. What is the drug of choice for management?
questions.solution:
The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.

Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

questions.text: A patient has presented to your OPD complaining of hearing loss following an attack of vertigo. He says he has had similar episodes in the past. You decide to prescribe him betahistine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The scenario given in the question likely points to a diagnosis of Meniere's disease. Betahistine is a selective H1 agonist used in this condition.

It causes vasodilation in the inner ear which improves circulation. Hence, it is used to treat vertigo in Meniere's disease.

questions.text:
The finding shown in the image below is seen as a side effect of which of the following drugs?
  1. Chloroquine
  2. Quinine
  3. Hydroxychloroquine
  4. Artesunate
  5. Lumefantrine
questions.solution:
The finding shown in the image is bulls-eye maculopathy, and chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine use are associated with this side effect.

Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a bull's-eye appearance to the macula.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus came to the OPD with a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. She was recently put on combination therapy. Her symptoms are least likely to be caused by which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Acarbose is least likely to cause hypoglycemia among the given options.

It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It inhibits the intestinal degradation and absorption of starch and disaccharides and thereby lowers the postprandial rise in glucose levels.

It has no role in stimulating insulin secretion and is therefore, least likely to cause hypoglycemia during monotherapy. 

Insulin and insulin secretagogues like sulfonylureas (gliclazide) and meglitinides (repaglinide) can result in hypoglycemia.

questions.text: The total microbial population was found to be susceptible to antimicrobials on testing but a subset of the same population was resistant which was undetected. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Heteroresistance occurs when a subset of the total microbial population is resistant, despite the total microbial population being susceptible on testing. The resistant subpopulation is usually well below the assay-detection limits. 

Heteroresistant Staphylococci and M. tuberculosis have led to therapeutic failures and mortality. C. albicans and C. neoformans with heteroresistance to fluconazole have resulted in increased treatment failures.

Note: For viruses, the resistant viral species occurring due to the above phenomenon is termed as 'quasi-species'. Quasi-species resistant to antiretroviral agents have resulted in the failure of antiretroviral therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cause carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
The only chemotherapeutic agent that has been proven to cause bladder cancer is cyclophosphamide.

The risk of the bladder cancer formation is linearly related to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment, supporting a causative role. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: An elderly man with a 30-year history of smoking complains of breathing difficulty. A diagnosis of COPD is made, and treatment with a long-acting muscarinic antagonist is initiated.  Which of the following will you not prescribe?
questions.solution:
Ipratropium is a short-acting muscarinic antagonist which is not used for the long-term management of COPD. It can be used to treat acute exacerbations.

The long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMAs) are:

  • Tiotropium
  • Glycopyrronium 
  • Umeclidinium
  • Aclidinium

questions.text: The culture and sensitivity report from a wound swab is positive for penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following antimicrobials can be administered?
questions.solution:
The drug that can be used here is cloxacillin since it is not penicillinase susceptible. It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.

Bacteria can inactivate β-lactam antibiotics by the action of the β-lactamase enzyme. The β-lactamases enzyme activity can be narrow or broad spectrum. In general, gram-positive bacteria produce and secrete a large amount of β-lactamase. Most of these enzymes are penicillinases.

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

Option B: Penicillin G encompasses the natural preparations and salts of penicillin. They have a narrow spectrum and are susceptible to penicillinase.

Options A and C: Amoxicillin and piperacillin are extended-spectrum penicillins but are susceptible to penicillinase.

questions.text: During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock being started on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
At lower doses (< 2 μg/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature, causing increased urine output.

As the dose increases (2-5 μg/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (β1) is also seen.

At very high doses (5-15 μg/kg), vasoconstriction (α1) is additionally seen.

questions.text: Neostigmine is administered to a post-op patient to reverse neuromuscular blockade. What is its mechanism of action?

choices.text: It blocks the action of acetylcholine
It interferes with the action of choline transferase
It interferes with the action of choline acetyl transferase
It interferes with the action of acetylcholine esterase

questions.solution:
Muscle weakness is improved by neostigmine as it interferes with the action of acetylcholine esterase.

Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used mainly to improve muscle tone in people with myasthenia gravis, and also to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants such as rocuronium and vecuronium at the end of an operation. 

Inhibition of acetylcholine esterase increases the acetylcholine levels in the synapse that can act on receptors over the large surface area and for longer periods of time, reducing the weakness.

questions.text: Which of the following are not reasons for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly?

choices.text: They have decreasing renal function with age
They have loss of lean body mass
Their total body water is decreased

questions.solution:
The reason for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly is decreased baroreceptor sensitivity due to age-related vascular stiffening.

Reasons for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly are:

  • Progressive decline of renal function (option A) 
  • Hepatic microsomal function is reduced, thus decreasing the metabolism of drugs with high hepatic extraction.
  • Loss of lean body mass and an increased ratio of fat to muscle (option B), leading to an increased volume of distribution (Vd) of lipophilic drugs 
  • Decreased body water (option D) causing decreased volume of distribution (Vd) of hydrophilic drugs
  • Slower absorption due to reduced gut motility.
  • Decreased plasma albumin concentration leading to decreased plasma protein binding.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was started on heparin postoperatively for thromboprophylaxis. After a week he developed sudden difficulty in breathing. His platelet count was found to be 70,000/microliter. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Alternative anticoagulant such as argatroban should be administered
Low molecular weight heparins should be avoided
Heparin should be replaced with warfarin

questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Direct thrombin inhibitors, such as argatroban is the anticoagulant of choice in HIT.

Management of HIT:

  • Stop heparin/LMWH
  • Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban
  • Do not give platelet transfusions (it only worsens the consumptive coagulopathy)
  • Do not give warfarin until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal.

Increased thrombin generation associated with HIT can cause consumption of protein C. Warfarin administration can further decrease protein C levels and cause skin necrosis. Therefore warfarin is avoided in HIT.

questions.text: A patient who is on statin therapy asks about a new drug called evolocumab that his friend is taking for hyperlipidemia. What is the route of administration of this drug?
questions.solution:
Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor that is administered as a subcutaneous injection.

PCSK-9 is a protease that binds to the LDL receptors on the surface of hepatocyte and enhances the lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptor. This results in higher plasma LDL levels. inhibition of PCSK-9 results in a reduction of plasma LDL levels. 

Two approved PCSK-9 inhibitors are alirocumab and evolocumab.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim?

choices.text: Duration of action is shorter than normal filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It should not be administered in sickle cell patients
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell anemia should not receive pegylated filgrastim as it can trigger a sickle cell crisis.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor). The pegylated forms of filgrastim, pegfilgrastim, and lipefilgrastim, are longer-acting forms. It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion only.

Indications of recombinant G-CSF:   

  • Severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
  • Severe neutropenia after high dose cancer chemotherapy
  • Severe congenital neutropenias
  • Neutropenia of patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine

Filgrastim is the first FDA-approved drug to treat patients with radiation-induced myelosuppression and to increase survival in such patients.

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient and teaching her the technique to self-administer insulin at home every day. Which of the following sites would you not suggest as the preferred site for insulin administration?
questions.solution:
The medial part of the thigh is not a preferred site for insulin administration in patients. This is because of the relatively higher density of blood vessels and nerves in this area. Another consideration is that the inner thighs rub together while walking and may cause soreness at the injection sites.

The preferred sites for insulin administration are:

  • Upper arm
  • Anterior and lateral aspects of the thigh
  • Buttocks
  • Abdomen (with the exception of a circle with a 2-inch radius around the navel)

Rotation of the injection site is important to prevent lipodystrophy. However, rotating within one area is recommended (e.g., rotating injections systematically within the abdomen) rather than rotating to a different area with each injection. This helps decrease variability in absorption from day to day.

questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is caused by:
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia is caused by prilocaine.

It is due to the metabolism of the aromatic ring of prilocaine to o-toluidine which is an oxidizing agent and oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin. Methemoglobinemia risk is directly associated with the total dose administered, usually appearing when doses exceed 8 mg/kg.

Intravenous administration of methylene blue is the treatment for methemoglobinemia.

Benzocaine can also cause methemoglobinemia similar to prilocaine.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of delamanid?
questions.solution:
Delamanid acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Pretomanid and delamanid are bicyclic nitroimidazoles that act by inhibiting mycolic acid (a component of the mycobacterial cell wall) and protein synthesis in the mycobacteria.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

In India, delamanid is only approved for the management of MDR-TB.

Isoniazid also acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Bedaquiline acts by inhibition of ATP synthase. It is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Option C: Fluoroquinolones act by inhibition of DNA gyrase. They are used as second-line agents in the treatment of tuberculosis.

Option D: Cycloserine is a D-alanine analogue used as a second-line drug for MDR-TB that acts by inhibition of alanine racemase. Alanine racemase converts L-alanine to D-alanine which is needed for the mycobacterial cell wall.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with hypertension, on treatment with methyldopa, comes for routine evaluation. She is found to have a positive Coombs test but is asymptomatic. What is the next course of action for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best course of action for the patient is close monitoring for any signs or symptoms of hemolysis.

Coombs test is done to test the presence of antibodies against Rh antigens on the red blood cells, which result in hemolysis. Positive Coombs test is seen in 20% of patients who receive methyldopa.

However, only 1-5% of such patients develop hemolytic anemia and hence, a positive Coombs test is not a necessary indication for stopping methyldopa treatment. They must be monitored closely and any signs that indicate hemolytic anemia needs prompt discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: 'Me-too drugs' do not differ significantly in which of the following pharmacological features as compared to the prototypical drug?
questions.solution:
Me-too drugs are chemically related to the prototype or other chemical compounds that have an identical mechanism of action. 

Various statins present in the market can be considered as "Me-too drugs". The pharmacokinetic parameters (absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination) vary significantly between them (atorvastatin and rosuvastatin have a very long duration of action), but the core mechanism of action remains the same: HMG CoA reductase inhibition and decrease in cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following organizations regulates the clinical trials and approval of investigational new drugs in India?
questions.solution:
Central Drug Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) regulates the clinical trials and approval of investigational new drugs in India. 

The CDSCO is also responsible for laying down the standards for drugs, controlling the quality of imported drugs in the country and coordinating the activities of State Drug Control Organizations. The proposal for initiating trials, review of clinical trial results, and recommendations for marketing authorization is done through a committee called the Investigational New Drug (IND) Committee formed by CDSCO. 

The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) is the head of the CDSCO, under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India. 

Preclinical trials are performed on animals, and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by the Committee for the Purpose of the Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals (CPCSEA) in India.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is brought to the casualty with complaints of swelling of his face and lips as shown in the image below. On further enquiry, it is noted that he has suffered from similar episodes in the past whenever he becomes emotional. He is prescribed icatibant. What is the likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing swelling of the face and lips is suggestive of hereditary angioedema. Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema.

The other drug which is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema is ecallantide which is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor. Both these drugs are administered subcutaneously.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recently approved another plasma kallikrein inhibitor, berotralstat, as the first oral drug for the prevention and treatment of hereditary angioedema.

questions.text: The efficacy of which of the following antiplatelet drugs will be reduced, if omeprazole is used concurrently?
questions.solution:
Clopidogrel is a prodrug that is converted into an active metabolite by the CYP2C19 enzyme and omeprazole can reduce the efficacy of clopidogrel due to its CYP2C19 inhibitory activity. 

Option B: Prasugrel is converted to its active metabolite mainly by other CYP enzymes and therefore omeprazole does not interfere in its activation.

Option C: Ticagrelor does not require activation and is metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme. 

Option D: Vorapaxar is a thrombin receptor antagonist that is also metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman diagnosed with breast carcinoma was prescribed trastuzumab. Which of the following statements regarding this drug is true?

choices.text: It is an antibody produced entirely from mouse containing no human component
It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting HER-2 antigen
It is a monoclonal antibody containing only human component

questions.solution:
Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the external domain of HER2/neu. In humanized antibodies, all components are identical to human antibodies (95% human component), except the complementary region of the variable chain that contains sequences from other species.

It is indicated in the management of adjuvant therapy in early and metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer. 

Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 tyrosine kinase receptor (HER-2-TK) inhibitors are:

  • Lapatinib
  • Neratinib

Anti-Her-2 monoclonal antibodies are:

  • Trastuzumab
  • Pertuzumab

The FDA recently approved tucatinib (kinase inhibitor) in combination with trastuzumab and capecitabine for the treatment of advanced unresectable breast cancer and metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer including brain metastasis.

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text: A researcher who was studying plasmodium species decided to visit a malaria-endemic place in Odisha to do his clinical study for 5 weeks. He is planning to leave after 2 days.  Which of the following drugs can be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline can be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic places.

Chemoprophylaxis against malaria for travelers:

  • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day is to be started 2 days before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.
  • If the duration of travel is more than 6 weeks then mefloquine 250mg once a week is to be started 2 weeks before travel and continued atleast 4 weeks after travel.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is methotrexate not used?
questions.solution:
Indications for methotrexate (inflammatory conditions) include:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Polymyositis
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Giant cell arteritis 
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Other systemic vasculitis
  • Graft versus host disease associated with organ transplantation.

Sickle cell anemia appears to be the most appropriate answer among the options. Though small trials have shown positive results in sickle cell disease, it is neither extensively used nor approved for this indication.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine?

choices.text: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.solution:
Colchicine acts by binding to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration.

Colchicine produces its anti-inflammatory effects by binding to the intracellular protein tubulin. This prevents the polymerization of tubulin into microtubules which is necessary for leukocyte migration and phagocytosis. Inhibition of microtubule formation prevents granulocyte migration and also arrests cell division at G1 phase.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs can be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG findings are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Verapamil and diltiazem are used in both acute treatment and prophylaxis of PSVT.

Their mechanism of action is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure.

Dihydropyridines like nifedipine and amlodipine do not have any antiarrhythmic property.

Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1A / 1C antiarrhythmics

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of heroin addiction is referred to a rehabilitation center. Which of the following would you use as a substitute drug for maintenance therapy?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used as a substitute drug for the maintenance therapy of opioid (heroin) dependence. This is because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. 

Due to its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence:

  • Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms
  • Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used
  • Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawal symptoms
  • LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving
  • Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the use of selegiline in Parkinsonism?

choices.text: It acts as a selective MAO A inhibitor
Incidence of cheese reaction is minimal
May be used for on / off phenomenon

questions.solution:
Selegiline acts as a selective MAO-B inhibitor.

At higher doses, MAO-A can also be inhibited. Higher doses are used for depression and administered in the form of the transdermal patch. 

Option B: Selective MAO-B inhibitors do not interfere significantly with the peripheral metabolism of dietary amines and do not cause cheese reaction.

Option C:  It has lower efficacy than levodopa but when added with levodopa it prolongs its action and also decreases the wearing-off effect of levodopa.

Option D: Selegiline forms metabolites like amphetamine and methamphetamine that can result in anxiety, insomnia, and other undesirable effects. Rasagiline, unlike selegiline, does not form amphetamines as metabolites.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Magnesium salts have a laxative property and can cause diarrhoea.

Aluminium salts can cause constipation by relaxing smooth muscles. 

The combination of aluminium and magnesium salts can neutralize each other’s action, thus the combination is preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following quinolones is not approved for use in a patient diagnosed with urinary tract infection?
questions.solution:
Moxifloxacin does not accumulate significantly in urine and is not approved for the treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

UTIs are the only indication for the use of nalidixic acid. Ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin can be used in UTIs caused by susceptible organisms.

questions.text: You are studying the susceptibility of Streptococci to bacitracin in the lab. What is the site of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Bacitracin acts on the cell wall by inhibiting the synthesis of the cell wall.

It interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol (lipid carrier) which carries peptidoglycan subunits outside the cell membrane to the growing cell wall. It can also alter the integrity of the cell membrane.

Bacitracin is mainly active against gram-positive cocci and bacilli.

questions.text: Which of the following is more likely to precipitate angina?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given calcium channel blockers, nifedipine is more likely to precipitate angina.

Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker having a rapid onset and short duration of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia. Increased contractility leads to an increase in O2 demand which may precipitate angina.

Option A: Amlodipine and extended-release preparations of nifedipine do not cause a steep fall in blood pressure and subsequent activation of sympathetic tone. Therefore, they are less likely to precipitate angina. 

Options C and D: Verapamil and diltiazem have relatively less action on peripheral vascular smooth muscles. They have a direct inhibitory effect on cardiac tissue causing negative ionotropic effect (verapamil > diltiazem).

questions.text: An elderly patient who was taken up for an emergency laparotomy showed prolonged respiratory depression which did not resolve with neostigmine.  On inquiry, the attendant confirmed that the patient was on aminoglycoside therapy. Which of the following is least likely to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts the neuromuscular blockade effect of aminoglycosides, and tobramycin has the least potency for blockade in this group.

Decreasing order of potency for the neuromuscular blockade is:

Neomycin > Kanamycin > Amikacin > Gentamicin > Tobramycin

It is a recognized clinical side effect of aminoglycoside antibiotics, and this effect becomes significant (prolonged respiratory depression) when the drug is used in conjunction with neuromuscular blocking agents or calcium channel blockers. They are avoided in patients with myasthenia gravis.

Aminoglycosides cause neuromuscular blockade by interfering with calcium channels and thereby inhibiting acetylcholine's pre-junctional release and post-junctional sensitivity. The neuromuscular blockade produced by these antibiotics is not reversed by neostigmine but is reversed by IV calcium gluconate.

questions.text: Which of the following antineoplastic agents is extracted from the plant shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the periwinkle plant (Catharanthus roseus). Vinca alkaloids like vinblastine and vincristine are extracted from this plant.

Sources of few other drugs are:

  • Epothilones - Myxobacterium Sorangium cellulosum
  • Camptothecin analogs - Camptotheca acuminata tree
  • Taxanes - bark of the western yew tree.

questions.text: A study was conducted to genotype NAT2 gene polymorphisms in patients receiving ATT. Among the 300 patients genotyped, 200 were slow acetylators (group A), 70 were intermediate (group B) and 30 were fast acetylators (group C). Patients in group A are prone to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid, a key agent in the ATT, is metabolized primarily through N-acetylation by the genetically polymorphic N-acetyltransferase-2 (NAT2) enzyme. Slow acetylators (group A) of isoniazid are prone to develop peripheral neuropathy.

The rate of metabolism of isoniazid is determined by the genetic polymorphism of NAT2 enzyme and classified broadly into two groups - slow and fast acetylators.

In slow acetylators, the drug accumulates due to slow metabolism resulting in an increased risk of side effects, and hence they should undergo periodic monitoring. Peripheral neuropathy is a more frequent side effect of INH when compared to hepatotoxicity.

Fast acetylators metabolize the drug rapidly and show less response to standard doses and the therapy may be less effective.

questions.text: A post-menopausal lady who is taking estrogen as part of her hormone replacement therapy reads about raloxifene on the internet and wants to change her current treatment. Which of the following is not an advantage of using raloxifene over estrogen?

choices.text: No increase in incidence of breast carcinoma

questions.solution:
Raloxifene causes a 3-fold increase in deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with the following actions:

  • Agonist actions:
    • Bone - increases bone mineral density and reduces the risk of vertebral fracture
    • Lipids - increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
  • Antagonist actions:
    • Breast - incidence of breast carcinoma is reduced 
    • Uterus - endometrial hyperplasia is avoided

questions.text: A patient with recent-onset primary generalized epilepsy develops a skin reaction due to phenytoin sodium. What is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Stop and restart phenytoin sodium after two weeks

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin warrants discontinuation of the drug. Switching to sodium valproate is the most appropriate course of action for this patient. 

Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents indicated for GTCS. Clonazepam and ethosuximide are primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for GTCS. 

Clonazepam is indicated as adjunctive therapy in the absence seizures when first-line agents (ethosuximide, sodium valproate, lamotrigine) fail to control the seizures adequately.

questions.text: A patient requires the shortest acting formulation of insulin to prevent postprandial hyperglycemia. Which of the following formulations would you choose?
questions.solution:
Inhaled insulin is the shortest acting formulation of insulin. 

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text: A patient with superficial bladder carcinoma is being treated with a drug by intravesical therapy. Identify this drug.
questions.solution:
Mitomycin C is used in the treatment of superficial transitional cell carcinoma by intravesical instillation. It is also used in upper gastrointestinal cancers (e.g. esophageal carcinoma), anal cancers, and breast cancers.

Topical mitomycin C is used in:

  • Superficial bladder cancer
  • Intraperitoneal tumors
  • Strabismus surgery to reduce scarring
  • To prevent tracheal and esophageal stenosis
  • Post nasal surgery synechae formation

questions.text: A patient presents with watery diarrhea, fever and abdominal pain. Investigations reveal a WBC count of 16,000 cells/microL. The patient has been on treatment with ampicillin for a few days. Which of the following antibiotics is approved for use in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile and fidaxomicin is a macrocyclic antibiotic that is indicated as an alternative to vancomycin in severe and recurring Clostridium difficile infections.

It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis through the blockade of RNA polymerase.

questions.text: The elimination after 3 half-lives in first-order kinetics is around:
questions.solution:
The proportion of drug eliminated after three half-lives in first-order kinetics is around 87.5%. 

After each half-life, 50% of the drug is eliminated or the plasma concentration becomes half the original value.

Therefore, after, 

  • 1 half-life = 50% drug is eliminated
  • 2 half-lives = 75% drug is eliminated
  • 3 half-lives = 87.5% is eliminated
  • 4 half-lives = 93% is eliminated

Thus, about 4-5 half lives are required for near-complete drug elimination.

questions.text: A patient is to be started on a cephalosporin antibiotic. His serum creatinine levels yesterday at the time of admission was 1.1 mg/dl and now it is 1.5 mg/dl. Which of the following cephalosporins can be started without dose reduction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute kidney injury and the cephalosporin that does not require dose reduction in this patient is cefoperazone.

All cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. They need a dose reduction in renal failure, except cefpiramide and cefoperazone that have predominant biliary excretion.

Dose reduction is necessary for cefoperazone and cefpiramide in patients with hepatic impairment.

questions.text: Sugammadex is a reversal agent for:
questions.solution:
Sugammadex is a reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.

Sugammadex binds to plasma rocuronium and thus decreases the plasma concentration of rocuronium. This forms a concentration gradient of rocuronium due to which it moves from the neuromuscular junction back into the circulation where it quickly bound by free sugammadex. It is not recommended to be used in patients who have severe renal impairment.

questions.text: Subfamily of CYP3A4 is _______
questions.solution:
The sub-family of CYP3A4 is A.

In CYP enzymes nomenclature, the root CYP is followed by a number designating the family, a letter denoting the subfamily and another number designating the gene. Therefore, in CYP3A4:

  • 3 - family 
  • A - subfamily A
  • 4 - individual gene coding for one specific isoenzyme

There are numerous CYP isoenzymes in humans. Among them, CYP3A4 is the most abundant and carries out the metabolism of nearly 50% of clinically used drugs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin on the sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia for the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone.

One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration of the skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immune response in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layers of skin.

The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose and photosensitivity.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Red man syndrome - Vancomycin
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.text: Which of the following ACE inhibitors is not a prodrug?
questions.solution:
Lisinopril is not a prodrug.

All ACE inhibitors are prodrugs except lisinopril and captopril.

questions.text: What is pegloticase used for?
questions.solution:
Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.

It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

questions.text: What is the current GINA recommendation for the prescription of long-acting β-2 agonists in patients suffering from bronchial asthma?

choices.text: In combination with an inhaled anticholinergic
In combination with an inhaled corticosteroid
In combination with a short acting β-2 agonist

questions.solution:
LABA is used in combination with inhalational corticosteroids (ICS), preferably in the form of a combination inhaler.

LABA is never taken alone as it does not treat the underlying chronic inflammation of asthma. Corticosteroids will decrease the underlying inflammation and halt the progression of the disease.

Short-acting β-2 agonists (SABA) can be given as an add-on therapy to the LABA-ICS combination (as-needed therapy).

questions.text: A sanitation worker presented with complaints of blurred vision, breathing difficulty and muscle weakness. He gave a history of spraying malathion this morning. You administer pralidoxime as an antidote. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Pralidoxime reactivates cholinesterase, which would have been deactivated by phosphorylation caused by malathion.

Pralidoxime attaches to the anionic site of the enzyme that remains unoccupied. Then it reacts with the phosphorus atom of the organophosphorous compound which is attached to the esteric site to form a phospho-oxime complex. It then dissociates from the enzyme, regenerating the active enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs approach zero-order kinetics at higher therapeutic levels?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin kinetics changes from first-order to zero-order kinetics at higher therapeutic levels.

True zero-order kinetics is shown only by ethanol. Some drugs have first-order kinetics at low plasma concentrations while at higher plasma concentration (within therapeutic range), the mechanism for elimination gets saturated and they change over to zero-order kinetics.

Drugs that show early saturation kinetics include: 

  • Warfarin
  • Aspirin
  • Theophylline
  • Verapamil
  • Fluoxetine
  • Phenytoin

Some drugs show zero-order kinetics at much higher (non-therapeutic / toxic) levels.

All the other options exhibit first order kinetics. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes activation of K+-ATP channels?
questions.solution:
Nicorandil causes activation of K+-ATP channels. This leads to the hyperpolarization of the smooth muscle cells leading to vasodilatation.

It also has nitrate like cGMP dependent action. Nicorandil dilates both arteries and veins leading to a decrease in afterload and preload of the heart.

Molsidomine, isosorbide dinitrate, and nitroglycerin are nitrates. They do not act on K-ATP channels.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: You observe a nurse administering an intramuscular injection to a patient in the clinic. Which of the following was likely being administered to the patient?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxoid is likely to be administered intramuscularly.

The intramuscular route (IM) of drug administration is mostly given in the deltoid, gluteal region, and anterolateral aspect of the thigh where the muscle is bulkier. This route bypasses the first-pass metabolism and reaches systemic circulation quickly. 

This method is suitable for moderate volumes, oily vehicles, and some irritating substances. Absorption of drugs in an aqueous solution after IM injection depends on the rate of blood flow to the injection site and can be relatively rapid. Thus, the injections given in the gluteal region are relatively more slowly absorbed in females than in males. Depot injections may produce slow and prolonged action. 

The Z-track technique is used for intramuscular injections in which the needle is inserted at 90 degrees with a quick darting movement. This prevents skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin. Pain intensity is also reduced.

 

Intramuscular injections are contraindicated if there is an active infection at the site of administration, coagulation defects, and thrombocytopenia.

Other routes of administration are oral (undergoes first-pass metabolism), intravenous (100% bioavailability and bypasses first-pass metabolism), subcutaneous, inhalational (e.g Metered dose inhaler, rotahaler), topical (including eye and skin preparations), and rectal.

Other options:

Options A and B: Test doses of drugs and BCG vaccines are administered intradermally.

Option D: Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is administered subcutaneously. Heparin can be given through intravenous and subcutaneous routes.

questions.text: A patient on intravenous vancomycin develops flushing and erythematous lesions. On examination, tachycardia, and hypotension are noted. By what mechanism does vancomycin cause these effects?

choices.text: Direct toxic effect on mast cells

questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts red man syndrome associated with vancomycin. It occurs due to a direct toxic effect on mast cells resulting in the release of histamine.

Red man or red neck syndrome is a non-allergic reaction due to rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin characterized by: 

  • Flushing
  • Erythematous, urticarial reactions
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension

Slow infusion, prophylactic use of antihistamines can reduce the incidence.

questions.text: The action of digoxin will not be affected in which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
The action of digoxin is not affected in chronic liver disease. 

Option B: Electrolyte disturbances like hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia increase digitalis toxicity.

Option C: Digoxin is excreted unchanged primarily by kidneys by glomerular filtration. Therefore, dose adjustment of digoxin has to be done in renal failure.

Option D: Chances of arrhythmias increases manifold in post-MI duration. Hence, it is generally avoided post-MI as digitalis itself causes arrhythmias.

  Digitoxin  Digoxin 
Oral absorption  Very good (90-100%)  Good ( 60-80%) i/v also 
Plasma protein binding   95%  25% 
Elimination  Hepatic metabolism  Renal excretion (by glomerular filtration) 
Dose adjustment in  Liver failure  Kidney failure

questions.text: The mechanism of action of pitolisant is:
questions.solution:
Pitolisant is an H3 receptor inverse agonist.

It has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of excessive daytime sleepiness in adults with narcolepsy.

Contraindications:

  • End-stage renal disease
  • Severe hepatic impairment

Other drugs used for the treatment of daytime sleepiness are:

  • Modafinil
  • Solriamfetol
  • Methylphenidate

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not act as a prokinetic agent by 5HT4 agonism?
questions.solution:
Domperidone does not have any 5HT4 agonist action. It mainly acts by D2 antagonist action.

5HT4 agonism and D2 antagonism can result in prokinetic action by increasing the cholinergic activity of the gut.

The 5HT4 agonist action is shown by:

  • Metoclopramide 
  • Cisapride
  • Mosapride
  • Itopride
  • Renzapride
